newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity seen up slightly on weather.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity seen up slightly on weather.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures were expected to open slightly higher Wednesday based on support from expectations of heating demand in the U.S. West, industry sources said.
"We're looking at possibly a dime higher on the front months," one Houston-based futures trader said.

May Palo Verde (PV) was called to open up 10 cents from Tuesday's settlement at $15.89 per megawatt hour (MWh), while May California Oregon Border (COB) was expected to open flat to 10 cents above Tuesday's settlement at $12.61 per MWh, the sources said.
May PV was assessed at $15.75-16.15 in early Wednesday over-the-counter discussion.
The futures contracts settled mostly lower Tuesday on forecasts of warmer temperatures and the return of several generating units from unplanned outages in the western U.S.

The units returning to service included the 1,073 megawatt (MW) Diablo Canyon nuclear unit 2 in Avila Beach, Calif., the 1,212 MW Helms pumped storage hydroelectric plant near Fresno, Calif., and the 750 MW Navajo coal-fired power plant near Page, Ariz.,
The futures decrease Tuesday was also partially attributed to lower physical power prices in the West due in part to forecasts of warmer weather.
But sources said weather forecasts could mean some additional power demand due to air conditioner use, especially in the U.S. Southwest.
Weather in the Pacific Northwest was forecast to be dry and mild through the weekend, averaging three to eight degrees above normal. Some possible precipitation was seen by Sunday.
Longer-term forecasts called for above-normal temperatures in the Pacific Northwest from April 20 to 24, with near normal temperatures in the northwest portion of the area during the same period.
In the Southwest, temperatures were expected to be three to 15 degrees above normal with dry conditions through the weekend. Temperatures were seen returning to near-normal levels early next week.
